p: In conclusion, we report that EOs isolated from selected Ferula species have antibacterial activity against MRSA USA300, which is a relevant clinical strain. The most active EOs were isolated from F. ovina and were characterized by an abundance of monoterpene hydrocarbons, oxygenated monoterpenes, and sesquiterpenes. On the other hand, F. iliensis EOs had low antibacterial activity, suggesting that ( E)-propenyl sec-butyl disulfide and ( Z)-propenyl sec-butyl disulfide do not have significant activity against MRSA. Finally, F. akitsckensis EOs possessed weak or no antibacterial activity. Although EOs from F. ovina demonstrated concentration-dependent inhibition of MRSA growth, their major constituents (α-pinene, β-pinene, and sabinene) had low activity, suggesting that they were not responsible for the observed bioactivity of the unfractionated EOs. On the other hand, correlation of the GC-MS data with antibacterial activity suggested that the sesquiterpene hydrocarbon eremophilene and the oxygenated monoterpene trans-verbenol could be the constituents responsible for antibacterial activity. Further studies are clearly necessary to evaluate efficacy and elucidate the exact mechanisms by which EOs from F. ovina exhibit their antibacterial effects.
